quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Ben was VP of product and growth at Thumbtack, where he rebuilt the product team and Thumbtack's growth strategy, re-architected the revenue model, and helped 3X Thumbtack's growth within three years.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete example of major org, growth, and monetization changes tied to a specific growth outcome (3X in three years).

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Prior to Thumbtack, Ben was at Lyft for over six years, where he was employee number 30 and led product and growth for the driver's side of the business, and at one point reached 1% of U.S. workers driving for Lyft every month.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Specific scale benchmark that signals what “massive” supply-side marketplace penetration can look like.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we go many layers deep on the many key elements of building and scaling a marketplace business, including what to focus on pre-product market fit, how to know which side of the marketplace to prioritize, what product market fit looks like, how to track liquidity, what causes most marketplaces to fail and how to avoid that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A practical checklist of core marketplace problem areas (PMF, side prioritization, liquidity, failure modes) that teams can use to structure their work.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: some really interesting stories about how Lyft was able to compete with Uber early on with one-tenth of the resources.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a counterintuitive competitive dynamic—winning despite far fewer resources—setting up learnings on leverage and strategy.

quotes.topic_title: What is a marketplace and managed spectrum
quotes.text: it's two or more sides that are distinct from one another, and they provide value to each other, and then you have an intermediary trying to facilitate that exchange of value in the middle.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A crisp, reusable definition of a marketplace that practitioners can apply to classify (or sanity-check) a business model.

quotes.topic_title: What is a marketplace and managed spectrum
quotes.text: I think in practice it's always a little bit more nuanced on the fringes.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A reminder that real-world marketplace boundaries are fuzzy, encouraging teams to look beyond textbook definitions when designing products and metrics.

quotes.topic_title: What is a marketplace and managed spectrum
quotes.text: how involved is the intermediary defines how managed the marketplace is.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A simple mental model for comparing marketplaces by the platform’s level of control over the transaction.

quotes.topic_title: What is a marketplace and managed spectrum
quotes.text: So, something like Craigslist is super hands-off, unmanaged, and something like Lyft starts to be more into the semi-managed where the platform significantly shapes the transaction in this exchange of value.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Concrete examples that anchor the “managed spectrum” concept and help practitioners place their own marketplace on that continuum.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Experimentation is increasingly essential for driving growth, and for understanding the performance of new features.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights experimentation as a core growth and product-learning discipline, not a nice-to-have.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo helps you increase experimentation velocity while unlocking rigorous deep analysis in a way that no other commercial tool does.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Frames the key lever as increasing experiment throughput without sacrificing analytical rigor.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Eppo does all that and more, with advanced statistical methods that can help you shave weeks off experiment time, an accessible UI for diving deeper into performance, and out-of-the-box reporting that helps you avoid annoying prolonged analytic cycles.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Actionable checklist of capabilities that reduce time-to-learning in experimentation programs.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But building these integrations in-house cost an average of three months of engineering, according to the 2024 State of Integration survey, which results in difficult roadmap tradeoffs.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Provides a concrete benchmark for integration build cost that can inform buy-vs-build decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: The result? They've shipped integrations seven times faster, all while avoiding the never-ending maintenance that comes with rolling your own integrations.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Quantifies the potential speedup and highlights maintenance as a hidden long-term cost.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace vs owning supply clarification
quotes.text: a key part of a marketplace is that the company doesn't own the supply.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Defines a core boundary condition practitioners can use to distinguish a true marketplace from a traditional seller or operator.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace vs owning supply clarification
quotes.text: you have companies that claim to be managed marketplaces, I think depending on how you want to look, with investors perhaps, you'll pick one angle or the other, but that's where you get into gray waters.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Highlights the “managed marketplace” gray area and how positioning can shift by audience, which affects strategy and narrative.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace vs owning supply clarification
quotes.text: the marketplace implies this concept of two independent and supposedly autonomous parties that you help connect and provide this exchange of value for them.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Offers a practical mental model for marketplace design: enable exchange between autonomous sides rather than acting as the supplier.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace vs owning supply clarification
quotes.text: it's something that every marketplace trends towards or thinks about is just like we're going to control the supply, we're going to manage it, we're going to maybe own it in the future, but let's get back to that.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Surfaces a common strategic temptation—moving toward controlling/owning supply—that operators should consciously evaluate as they scale.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest early mistake: overthinking marketplace dynamics
quotes.text: If you don't have product market fit, and if you don't have a good enough growth strategy for at least one side of your marketplace, just forget about all this marketplace stuff.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A contrarian prioritization rule: before PMF, ignore marketplace theory and focus on nailing PMF plus a growth engine for one side.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest early mistake: overthinking marketplace dynamics
quotes.text: Focus on this core exchange of value, go deep with one side of the marketplace and see if you can rely on some crutch, some hack for the other side for time being.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A practical early-stage methodology: concentrate on the core value exchange and drive one side while temporarily “propping up” the other.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest early mistake: overthinking marketplace dynamics
quotes.text: And you see companies like Airbnb and Thumbtack doing this with Craigslist pretty early on to jumpstart their growth as just countless examples,
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Concrete example of using an external platform as a “crutch” to bootstrap marketplace liquidity and growth.

quotes.topic_title: Biggest early mistake: overthinking marketplace dynamics
quotes.text: but don't get distracted by this shiny and cool intellectually challenging idea of working on the marketplace, and nail the basics of your product market fit at first.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A reminder to avoid over-optimizing marketplace mechanics before validating the product’s core demand and value.

quotes.topic_title: Which side to prioritize and early hacks
quotes.text: Which side to focus on is there's different approaches to this, but generally people will pick the hardest side.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A simple decision rule for early marketplaces: prioritize the side that’s hardest to acquire/retain rather than the one that seems most obvious.

quotes.topic_title: Which side to prioritize and early hacks
quotes.text: So, Thumbtack is a home services marketplace to help you find plumbers, electricians, and the harder side there was demand.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A counterintuitive example where demand—not supply—was the bottleneck, challenging the common “supply-first” default.

quotes.topic_title: Which side to prioritize and early hacks
quotes.text: Pick the hardest side is my advice.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A memorable, repeatable heuristic founders can apply when deciding which side of a marketplace to focus on first.

quotes.topic_title: Which side to prioritize and early hacks
quotes.text: Find a way to hack one side, play one player mode is what it's also called sometimes, but try to find a way to tap into existing channels that have one side of your marketplace already latent.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Introduces a practical bootstrapping methodology (“one player mode”) for jumpstarting liquidity by leveraging existing ecosystems.

quotes.topic_title: Which side to prioritize and early hacks
quotes.text: When we have someone who wants a job, 'Oh, you want your kitchen remodeled?' We can, behind the scenes, go and post a job on Craigslist and then we'll bring on all the contractors who are browsing Craigslist looking for jobs, we'll bring them to our platform.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A concrete growth hack example: use Craigslist as a supply acquisition channel to fulfill demand and bootstrap early marketplace liquidity.

quotes.topic_title: Supply growth tactics and rider-to-driver conversion
quotes.text: I would say supply is the hardest side maybe like 80% to 90% of the time.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A practical rule-of-thumb for marketplace builders on where the hardest growth constraint usually sits.

quotes.topic_title: Supply growth tactics and rider-to-driver conversion
quotes.text: Yeah, I think there's a couple of common tactics I would say pretty early on that I think companies rely on.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Sets up a repeatable set of early-stage supply growth levers practitioners can test.

quotes.topic_title: Supply growth tactics and rider-to-driver conversion
quotes.text: You have also a lot of companies building value added services pretty early on as a core way of retaining supply pretty early on.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Highlights a concrete retention strategy: win supply by bundling compelling tools/services, not just demand.

quotes.topic_title: Supply growth tactics and rider-to-driver conversion
quotes.text: In our case at Lyft early on, we had a waitlist on the demand side because we just couldn't onboard enough supply.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A specific example showing demand can be abundant while supply onboarding is the true bottleneck.

quotes.topic_title: Supply growth tactics and rider-to-driver conversion
quotes.text: To me, liquidity is how marketplaces win.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A memorable north-star framing for scaling marketplaces: optimize for efficient matching, not just growth.

quotes.topic_title: Liquidity as the core scaling challenge
quotes.text: To me, liquidity is how marketplaces win.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A crisp thesis statement that frames liquidity as the primary driver of marketplace success and scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Liquidity as the core scaling challenge
quotes.text: To me, liquidity is how marketplaces win. It's this measure of your ability to match buyers and sellers efficiently, it's how quickly and efficiently people can find what they're looking for on your platform.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Defines liquidity in operational terms practitioners can measure and optimize (matching efficiency and time-to-find).

quotes.topic_title: Liquidity as the core scaling challenge
quotes.text: So, you can picture a Venn diagram. One circle is this is what supply wants to sell, and another circle is this is what demand wants to buy, and your liquidity is the overlap between those two circles.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A simple mental model for diagnosing liquidity by focusing on overlap between supply and demand preferences.

quotes.topic_title: Liquidity as the core scaling challenge
quotes.text: It might be for all the people who open the app with the intention to book a ride, how many of those actually turn into a ride?
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, actionable example of a liquidity metric (intentful demand conversion to transactions).

quotes.topic_title: Liquidity as the core scaling challenge
quotes.text: And what I see is people missing how critical this component is in the marketplace, struggle to define it for the business, and most importantly struggle to build an actionable playbook against it. Like, "Okay, how do I manage this? Okay, it's important, but what do I do about it?" Basically.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Highlights a common failure mode: recognizing liquidity matters but not translating it into a defined metric and operating playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring liquidity: fill rate and predictors
quotes.text: I think the metric that I like the most is a predictor of liquidity.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Shifts the focus from measuring liquidity as an output to identifying leading indicators teams can actually influence.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring liquidity: fill rate and predictors
quotes.text: It's what I call a market health metric, and this is basically think of your proxy that is the best predictor of your liquidity.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Introduces a practical methodology: define a single proxy metric that predicts liquidity and can guide execution.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring liquidity: fill rate and predictors
quotes.text: For Lyft and for Uber, it was ETAs.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Gives a concrete example of a market-health proxy that strongly drives conversion decisions in ride-hailing.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring liquidity: fill rate and predictors
quotes.text: So find this threshold, find this predictor that tends to plateau that correlates strongly with retention but with also the transaction happening, and that's the metric that you can predict.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Actionable guidance for teams: identify the nonlinear “threshold” point where improving the predictor stops yielding meaningful gains.

quotes.topic_title: Measuring liquidity: fill rate and predictors
quotes.text: That's a metric that's so much more actionable for teams to work against.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Explains why leading proxies beat output metrics for day-to-day team goals and prioritization.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit in marketplaces: two-sided PMF
quotes.text: Maybe this is a hot take, but I feel like product market fit is independent of your marketplace dynamics.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Contrarian framing that PMF should be evaluated like any other product, not conflated with marketplace liquidity/flywheel issues.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit in marketplaces: two-sided PMF
quotes.text: You might have a great product, and it provides amazing value to both sides, but you have yet to crack the flywheel on the supply side for how to bring those people.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Highlights that marketplace growth mechanics (e.g., supply acquisition) can lag even when the core product is strong.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit in marketplaces: two-sided PMF
quotes.text: And so, to me, my answer would tend to be pretty classical, it would be like measure your product market fit the way you would for a normal company.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Actionable advice to use standard PMF measurement approaches rather than inventing marketplace-specific proxies.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit in marketplaces: two-sided PMF
quotes.text: I like the classic if we were to take this product away, what percentage of users would be significantly disappointed or have no other solution?
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Points to a concrete methodology (Sean Ellis-style survey) for assessing PMF in a marketplace context.

quotes.topic_title: Product-market fit in marketplaces: two-sided PMF
quotes.text: I think here my advice is typically to consider that you have two product market fits essentially.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Memorable mental model that marketplaces require distinct PMF on both demand and supply sides.

quotes.topic_title: When a marketplace model makes sense
quotes.text: I think the signs that come to mind are one, higher fragmentation. I think you want this long tail of buyers and sellers without a handful of big players controlling the market, because this is where you can provide value by doing this job of aggregation.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A clear signal/framework for when a marketplace model is structurally advantaged: fragmented supply and demand where aggregation creates value.

quotes.topic_title: When a marketplace model makes sense
quotes.text: I think you also want a relatively uniform set of needs. That means that it can be, like your supply can be commoditized to some extent.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A practical heuristic: marketplaces work better when demand can be matched to interchangeable supply rather than highly bespoke preferences.

quotes.topic_title: When a marketplace model makes sense
quotes.text: And the last one I'd mention is a high enough bearer in the matchmaking or the creation. I think how hard it is for people to find each other today, and how much effort do they have to put in to vet each other, I think is another great sign. The higher it is, the bigger the opportunity because it means you come in, implement the right processes to simplify this exchange of value.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A third marketplace “green light”: high search/vetting friction that a platform can reduce with process and product design.

quotes.topic_title: When a marketplace model makes sense
quotes.text: So, I think people who build marketplaces tend to want to give a lot of control to the users because this is what users want, or this is what comes up oftentimes in user feedback like, "Oh, we have those two distinct group of users. Those ones, they really want new cars. Those ones, they don't want new cars." And so, naturally you have a product team that builds the toggle to get the new cars, and I think the mistake is that you unknowingly fragment your supply in a way that has a much more meaningful impact on the health of your marketplace than you suspect.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product lesson: adding user choice/filters can silently destroy liquidity by fragmenting supply and harming marketplace health.

quotes.topic_title: When a marketplace model makes sense
quotes.text: And unknowingly to them, obviously, only 5% of our DJs had a smoke machine, and so you would carve out 95% of our supply.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A concrete data point illustrating how seemingly minor preference filters can wipe out liquidity and degrade the marketplace experience.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces fail: liquidity, ignoring a side, quality
quotes.text: So, you need to kick off this flywheel, you need to build enough of that density within your marketplace. And depending on the business, you can take a lot of time or money, and without the right diagnostic framework you can end up running out of both.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Highlights liquidity/density as the core marketplace hurdle and the need for a diagnostic framework to avoid burning time and capital before reaching it.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces fail: liquidity, ignoring a side, quality
quotes.text: And my advice is, if you're doing this you're missing out on half of your business.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A blunt warning to marketplaces that over-focus on demand acquisition while neglecting supply-side needs.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces fail: liquidity, ignoring a side, quality
quotes.text: And the trick is marketplaces are very laggy, so once your network effects start to die down it turns into this moment of panic of, "Oh shoot, we forgot about half of our users. We forgot that sellers are people too, and they're all leaving, and now we need to completely transform our product to save the ship, and to create a compelling value proposition on their side."
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Explains the delayed feedback loop in marketplaces and how neglecting one side can trigger a sudden, existential collapse.

quotes.topic_title: Why marketplaces fail: liquidity, ignoring a side, quality
quotes.text: You need to be intentional about the quality that you aim to provide, and I think a lot of companies don't have necessarily that intentionality and you have this constant push of supply, "If only we'd lower our bar a little bit, we could get more supply."
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Frames quality as an explicit strategic choice and warns against the common temptation to lower standards just to grow supply.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Airbnb doesn't own homes, Uber doesn't employee drivers.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Concrete examples illustrating why marketplaces inherently struggle with quality control when they don’t own supply.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: They can't even legally tell them exactly what to do because their contractors, so quality is always this ongoing challenge with marketplaces.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a structural/legal constraint that makes quality management a persistent, not one-time, problem in marketplaces.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So, there's always this push towards making it more of a managed marketplace.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Names the common strategic response—moving along the spectrum toward more control—to address marketplace quality issues.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And in a perfect world, not unlike an idealized world, quality will be best if you own it. But then you're no longer marketplace, your business model sucks.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tradeoff: maximizing quality by owning supply can undermine the marketplace model itself.

quotes.topic_title: Managed marketplaces: guardrails, coaching, and tradeoffs
quotes.text: I think when you're running a marketplace, you tend to sit in your ivory tower a little bit looking at stats and thinking, "If only we could get people to do X, it'd be better for everyone."
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Warns operators that top-down, metrics-driven control can miss real human motivations on the supply side.

quotes.topic_title: Managed marketplaces: guardrails, coaching, and tradeoffs
quotes.text: And digital, great. We knew we were going to improve their ROI by something like 20% maybe, and we launched this and pros hated it.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Concrete example that even objectively better economics can fail if it clashes with supplier psychology and preferences.

quotes.topic_title: Managed marketplaces: guardrails, coaching, and tradeoffs
quotes.text: And so, no matter what the data says of like, "Oh, we increased their earnings by 20%," the pros don't feel this way and it's the right to feel however they want.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Highlights perception as a first-class product constraint—supplier sentiment can override measured improvements.

quotes.topic_title: Managed marketplaces: guardrails, coaching, and tradeoffs
quotes.text: So, my call-out here is any attempt at control can be really tricky and backfire in ways that are unpredictable.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A practical caution for managed-marketplace interventions: control can create second-order effects you won’t model in advance.

quotes.topic_title: Managed marketplaces: guardrails, coaching, and tradeoffs
quotes.text: So, provide guardrails for what a good experience is in your marketplace, set a clear bar for quality, and provide the right coaching and tools for supply to be successful. And then take a step back and see where the gaps are, and invest more in hands-on tactics just to close those gaps more specifically.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A stepwise operating framework for improving quality without over-managing: guardrails → coaching/tools → targeted hands-on fixes.

quotes.topic_title: Quality without full management: Toptal example
quotes.text: They have a really high bar for quality, they claim to only have the top 1%, top 3% I believe, of talent there.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A concrete example of using strict supply-side standards as a primary quality lever in a marketplace.

quotes.topic_title: Quality without full management: Toptal example
quotes.text: This funny story from them, but apparently they advertise something maybe a 3% pass rate for their talent, so they only on board like 3% of the people who apply.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Shows how an explicit acceptance-rate metric can operationalize and signal quality to the market.

quotes.topic_title: Quality without full management: Toptal example
quotes.text: And allegedly their actual pass rate is even lower than that, but they thought that if they actually advertise the actual number it would sound fake.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Counterintuitive lesson: being “too elite” can reduce credibility, so quality signaling must be believable.

quotes.topic_title: Quality without full management: Toptal example
quotes.text: So, they're one company that does a tremendous amount of work for vetting quality early on with a ton of different checks, but also maintaining that quality. So, throughout with the right coaching tools, with education and things like that.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A practical methodology: combine upfront vetting with ongoing enablement to sustain quality without fully managing supply.

quotes.topic_title: Lyft rental fleet: manufacturing supply strategically
quotes.text: And so, by renting cars we could essentially manufacture our own supply. We could dial this up and down, we could be very surgical about how many vehicles do we bring in, which markets do we bring this in, at what price?
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A concrete managed-supply lever for marketplaces: create supply directly and control it with market-by-market, price-by-price precision.

quotes.topic_title: Lyft rental fleet: manufacturing supply strategically
quotes.text: And when we looked at the market, we realized that 50% of the job seekers and welfare recipients in the U.S. don't have a car.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A specific data point that reframes the growth bottleneck as an access problem (no car), not just recruiting/onboarding efficiency.

quotes.topic_title: Lyft rental fleet: manufacturing supply strategically
quotes.text: In the markets where we thought the vehicles of quality was too low, we knew we could onboard more rental vehicles that were more recent to raise the average age of a vehicle on the platform.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: Shows how managed supply can be used surgically to improve marketplace quality metrics (vehicle recency) in targeted geographies.

quotes.topic_title: Lyft rental fleet: manufacturing supply strategically
quotes.text: I think in few months we had built a rental company from the ground up, and within 18 months I think we were the fourth-largest rental fleet in the U.S.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: A vivid execution and scale example demonstrating how quickly a marketplace can operationalize a new supply-side business line.

quotes.topic_title: Lyft rental fleet: manufacturing supply strategically
quotes.text: we could offer to pay for the car but only if you don't drive for the competition for Uber, and only if you drive at least 30 hours a week.
quotes.speaker: Benjamin Lauzier
quotes.context: An explicit retention/loyalty mechanism: tie subsidies to exclusivity and minimum activity to increase engagement and reduce multi-homing.
